segment.source: title: Use the light sensor
segment.target: title: Use the light sensor

segment.source: description: Learn how to use the ambient light sensor to detect changes in lighting.
segment.target: description: Learn how to use the ambient light sensor to detect changes in lighting.

segment.source: Use the light sensor
segment.target: Use the light sensor

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: ** Important APIs **
segment.target: ** Important APIs **

segment.source: Windows.Devices.Sensors
segment.target: Windows.Devices.Sensors

segment.source: LightSensor
segment.target: LightSensor

segment.source: Learn how to use the ambient light sensor to detect changes in lighting.
segment.target: Learn how to use the ambient light sensor to detect changes in lighting.

segment.source: An ambient light sensor is one of the several types of environmental sensors that allow apps to respond to changes in the user's environment.
segment.target: An ambient light sensor is one of the several types of environmental sensors that allow apps to respond to changes in the user's environment.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: You should be familiar with Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), Microsoft Visual C#, and events.
segment.target: You should be familiar with Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), Microsoft Visual C#, and events.

segment.source: The device or emulator that you're using must support an ambient light sensor.
segment.target: The device or emulator that you're using must support an ambient light sensor.

segment.source: Create a simple light-sensor app
segment.target: Create a simple light-sensor app

segment.source: This section is divided into two subsections.
segment.target: This section is divided into two subsections.

segment.source: The first subsection will take you through the steps necessary to create a simple light-sensor application from scratch.
segment.target: The first subsection will take you through the steps necessary to create a simple light-sensor application from scratch.

segment.source: The following subsection explains the app you have just created.
segment.target: The following subsection explains the app you have just created.

segment.source: Instructions
segment.target: Instructions

segment.source: Create a new project, choosing a Blank App (Universal Windows) from the Visual C# project templates.
segment.target: Create a new project, choosing a Blank App (Universal Windows) from the Visual C# project templates.

segment.source: Open your project's BlankPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.
segment.target: Open your project's BlankPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.

segment.source: You'll need to rename the namespace in the previous snippet with the name you gave your project.
segment.target: You'll need to rename the namespace in the previous snippet with the name you gave your project.

segment.source: For example, if you created a project named LightingCS, you'd replace with .
segment.target: For example, if you created a project named LightingCS, you'd replace with .

segment.source: Open the file MainPage.xaml and replace the original contents with the following XML.
segment.target: Open the file MainPage.xaml and replace the original contents with the following XML.

segment.source: You'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.
segment.target: You'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.

segment.source: For example, if you created a project named LightingCS, you'd replace with .
segment.target: For example, if you created a project named LightingCS, you'd replace with .

segment.source: You should also replace with .
segment.target: You should also replace with .

segment.source: Press F5 or select Debug > Start Debugging to build, deploy, and run the app.
segment.target: Press F5 or select Debug > Start Debugging to build, deploy, and run the app.

segment.source: Once the app is running, you can change the light sensor values by altering the light available to the sensor or using the emulator tools.
segment.target: Once the app is running, you can change the light sensor values by altering the light available to the sensor or using the emulator tools.

segment.source: Stop the app by returning to Visual Studio and pressing Shift+F5 or select Debug > Stop Debugging to stop the app.
segment.target: Stop the app by returning to Visual Studio and pressing Shift+F5 or select Debug > Stop Debugging to stop the app.

segment.source: Explanation
segment.target: Explanation

segment.source: The previous example demonstrates how little code you'll need to write in order to integrate light-sensor input in your app.
segment.target: The previous example demonstrates how little code you'll need to write in order to integrate light-sensor input in your app.

segment.source: The app establishes a connection with the default sensor in the BlankPage method.
segment.target: The app establishes a connection with the default sensor in the BlankPage method.

segment.source: The app establishes the report interval within the BlankPage method.
segment.target: The app establishes the report interval within the BlankPage method.

segment.source: This code retrieves the minimum interval supported by the device and compares it to a requested interval of 16 milliseconds (which approximates a 60-Hz refresh rate).
segment.target: This code retrieves the minimum interval supported by the device and compares it to a requested interval of 16 milliseconds (which approximates a 60-Hz refresh rate).

segment.source: If the minimum supported interval is greater than the requested interval, the code sets the value to the minimum.
segment.target: If the minimum supported interval is greater than the requested interval, the code sets the value to the minimum.

segment.source: Otherwise, it sets the value to the requested interval.
segment.target: Otherwise, it sets the value to the requested interval.

segment.source: The new light-sensor data is captured in the ReadingChanged method.
segment.target: The new light-sensor data is captured in the ReadingChanged method.

segment.source: Each time the sensor driver receives new data from the sensor, it passes the value to your app using this event handler.
segment.target: Each time the sensor driver receives new data from the sensor, it passes the value to your app using this event handler.

segment.source: The app registers this event handler on the following line.
segment.target: The app registers this event handler on the following line.

segment.source: These new values are written to a TextBlock found in the project's XAML.
segment.target: These new values are written to a TextBlock found in the project's XAML.
